channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.

Real-time in-situ magnetization reprogramming for soft robotics

item.title: Synthesis of bulk hexagonal diamond
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09343-x

The synthesis, recovery and detailed characterization of bulk hexagonal diamond under high pressure and temperature conditions using precursor graphite carbon is described, demonstrating the first successful synthesis in the 100 µm to millimetre size range.
item.dc:title: Synthesis of bulk hexagonal diamond
item.dc:creator: Liuxiang Yang
Kah Chun Lau
Zhidan Zeng
Dongzhou Zhang
Hu Tang
Bingmin Yan
Guoliang Niu
Huiyang Gou
Yanping Yang

Duan Luo
Ho-kwang Mao

item.title: Direct observation of coherent elastic antineutrino–nucleus scattering
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09322-2

Direct observation of coherent elastic neutrino–nucleus scattering is reported using the data from the CONUS+ experiment in which the antineutrinos with energy less than 10 MeV are produced in a nuclear reactor.
item.dc:title: Direct observation of coherent elastic antineutrino–nucleus scattering
item.dc:creator: N. Ackermann

item.title: Invariance of dynamo action in an early-Earth model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09334-y

Early-Earth geometry models are presented, producing magnetic field intensity and morphologies agreeing with palaeomagnetic data in the deep past and demonstrating the negligible role of fluid viscosity in the Earth’s early geodynamo.
item.dc:title: Invariance of dynamo action in an early-Earth model
item.dc:creator: Yufeng Lin
Philippe Marti
Andrew Jackson

item.title: Miniature neutrino detector promises to test laws of physics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02404-1

Neutrinos from a nuclear reactor are caught by a technique known as coherent scattering.
item.dc:title: Miniature neutrino detector promises to test laws of physics
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi
